newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee futures driven by new fund buying.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee futures driven by new fund buying.

text.p: LIFFE coffee futures gathered some upward momentum on the back of renewed fund buying on Monday but prices ended below the day's peaks.
Traders said that despite the slight pullback, the closing levels were still encouraging. Some also said fund buying, the driving factor behind recent sharp rally, could continue.
"It wasn't a bad close...it looks very good still," said one. Origin sellers continued to step back while roasters remained reluctant buyers.
By the finish, March stood $35 higher at $1,535 a tonne after failing to break above $1,553.
The New York market also gained from a new wave of fund demand but traders said the March contract failed to break solid resistance at 145.25 cents a lb.
However, the market's recent upswing remained intact.

Surprisingly, today's advance came despite what many traders termed a bearish CFTC Commitment of Traders report which showed a net increase in speculative (non-commercial and non-reportable) long positions.

Earlier in the day, traders said the London market was supported by trade shortcovering on news that Indonesia would slice first half 1997 exports by 150,000 60-kg bags as part of a producer pact to limit robusta supplies and lift prices.
The market's volume reached a modest 4,085 lots, dominated by switch trades in March and May which changed hands at level money at one stage.
An Indonesian industry official said at the start of a three-day International Coffee Organisation executive board meeting that the Indonesian decision was final.

"The remaining 850,000 bags will have to be allocated among African and other robusta producers," the official said. Under the agreement reached in Brazil two weeks ago, robusta exports would have to be cut by a further 1.0 million bags and arabica by 300,000.
Robusta producers are expected to meet on Thursday in Bali, Indonesia, following the ICO meeting to decide on quota allocation. But by Monday, the meeting was yet to be confirmed.
In other developments, major Dutch roaster Douwe Egberts said it would be raising its retail prices in response to the sharp rise in world prices.
The move by Douwe Egberts came in the wake of a similar price hike by German roaster Eduscho late last month.
